title: Vatican cash crisis: Holy See loses €44million in a year as donations plummet
text:
The Vatican is rapidly losing money with donations plummeting as sex abuse scandals damage the Catholic Church's reputation, according to a new book.

Gianluigi Nuzzi writes that the Vatican lost nearly €44million (£38million) last year while its property empire made a loss for the first time.

The Italian journalist, whom the Vatican attempted to put on trial for publishing leaked secrets in 2016, said attempted reforms by Pope Francis were being 'anaesthetised, blocked and sabotaged' by Vatican insiders.

In the book, Universal Judgment, he claims that the Vatican faces a possible default on its debts by 2023, according to The Times.

Italian journalist Gianluigi Nuzzi (pictured near St Peter's Basilica in 2016) claims that the Vatican lost nearly €44million last year while its property empire made a loss for the first time

Attempted reforms by Pope Francis (pictured in the Holy See last week) are being 'anaesthetised, blocked and sabotaged' by Vatican insiders, it is claimed

His book is based on 3,000 confidential documents, which allegedly show that donations have fallen by 40 per cent in the space of three years.

Total donations dropped from more than €100million in 2016 to a mere €60million in the most recent figures, according to Nuzzi's research.

Vatican bosses encourage worshippers to donate to the collection, known as Peter's Pence, in order to 'participate in the Pope's activity'.

However, most of the donations are now used to cover the Vatican's general costs rather than for philanthropic work, it is claimed.

The Vatican has responded by setting up an emergency task force after losses mounted last year, Nuzzi says.

'Pope Francis's reforms of the Vatican's finances are failing, like a plaster placed on a haemorrhage,' the author said.

Francis, who was elected to the papacy in 2013, tried to reform Vatican finances by naming Australian cardinal George Pell as Vatican economy minister.

But Pell has since been disgraced in a child sex abuse case back in Australia and insiders believe reforms are being 'sabotaged'.

Worshippers in St Peter's Square where the Vatican is said to be facing a cash crisis with donations drying up

Cardinal George Pell (pictured after losing his appeal last month) has filed for special leave to appeal his child sex abuse convictions to the High Court of Australia

The cardinal was convicted of molesting two 13-year-old choirboys in a Melbourne cathedral in the 1990s.

His conviction was upheld in August this year, although Pell is now seeking a final appeal to Australia's highest court.

Pell's downfall was one of a series of sex scandals which have rocked the Catholic Church with clergymen and Vatican officials frequently accused of cover-ups.

Nuzzi, who wrote the new book, rose to fame with a major expose on the Holy See's shadowy finances, which was published in 2009.

Vatican prosecutors tried to put Nuzzi and another journalist on trial in a Vatican court in 2015 for publishing books based on leaked documents.

However, the Vatican's criminal court declared in July 2016 that it had no jurisdiction to prosecute them.

Nuzzi and the other journalist were not Vatican public officials and the alleged crime did not take place on Vatican territory, the court ruled.

Media watchdogs had criticised the trial and said it 'cast a chilling effect on covering the Vatican'.

Two other people were convicted for conspiring to leak the documents.

One clergyman, Lucio Vallejo Balda, admitted he gave Nuzzi 85 passwords to protected documents.
